Eric Prouzeta, Alain Michalowiczbc, Val~rie Gaborita, Abdelilah Nadiria, Michel Danota'* aLaboratoire de Chimie des Solides, IMN, CNRS-Universit~ de Nantes, UMR 6502, 2 rue de la Houssinibre. B.P. 32229, 44322 Nantes Cidex 3, France bLaboratoire de Physique des Milieux Dgsordonn~s, Faculti des Sciences et Technologies, Universiti Paris XIL Avenue du G~n~ral de Gaulle, 94000 Cr~teil, France CLURE, Universit~ de Paris-Sud, CNRS Bdttiment 209 D, 91405 Orsay Cddex, France dLaboratoire de Chimie Mindrale AppliquEe, Facult~ des Sciences, Universit~ Moulay lsmaiL BP 4010, Beni M'hamed, Meknks, Morocco Received 4 December 1996; received in revised form 14 February 1997; accepted 14 February 1997 Abstract We present a Nb K-edge EXAFS study of carbon- and alumina-supported niobium sulfide hydrotreatment catalysts. NbS2 and NbS3 entities have been evidenced on the carbon support, and NbS2 and Nbl_yS ones on the alumina support. EXAFS spectra of carbon-supported species, which are highly disordered, were analyzed through an asymmetric distance distribution model. Considering their poor dispersion, Nbl_yS species can be thought to be intrinsically highly active. Their activity, and that of NbS3 entities as well, can possibly be related to cation clustering. Niobium sulfides appear as very sensitive to support effects. Keywords." Niobium sulfides; Carbon support; Alumina support; EXAFS; Hydrotreatment I. Introduction Much work devoted to hydrotreatment catalysts concerns the improvement of the more traditional formulations (CoMo, NiMo .... ). However, non-conventional catalysts are also of interest, both technologically and intellectually, a case in point being the example of the niobium sulfides. The first studies of unsupported niobium sulfides gave somewhat different results. In their early survey of transition * Corresponding author. Allali et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 333-354 metal sulfides as hydrodesulfurization catalysts, Pecoraro and Chianelli [1] measured for niobium sulfide a rather low activity. Lewis and Kenney [2], on the other hand, have shown the disulfide NbS2 to be an effective catalyst for the isomerization and hydrogenation of 1-butene, despite very low surface areas of their samples. Besides, Kondratev et al. observed that cobalt-doping can induce a 50% increase of the activity of NbS2 [3]. Some years later, several unsupported niobium sulfides, the trisulfide NbSs, the disulfide NbS2, and the non-stoichio- metric disulfide Nbl+xS2, were tested in several hydrotreatment model-reactions (hydrodesulfurization, hydrodenitrogenation, hydrogenation) [4,5]. If compared to molybdenum disulfide, niobium sulfides showed interesting activities, a remark- able ability to cleave C-N and C-C bonds, and a high selectivity for hydrogenation [5,6]. It was found that the trisulfide NbS3 is more active than the disulfides NbS2, Nbl+xS2, and MoS2. This is probably related to the electronic particularities of niobium trisulfide which, contrary to the disulfides, presents anion- and cation- pairing, as evidenced from a structural point of view by the existence of short interanionic and intercationic distances (ds-s =2.05 ,~ and dNb-Nb =3.04 ,~) [7]. The interest of niobium sulfides being clearly demonstrated from the catalytic performances of unsupported samples, the study of related supported systems was undertaken, using carbon and alumina supports [8,9]. According to the synthesis route and nature of the support, large differences in activity were observed. Even if differences in the dispersion play an important role, identification of the active phase(s) can be of interest for a better understanding of these systems, particularly concerning their structural and electronic characteristics. However, no informative X-ray diffraction pattern has been obtained for these supported catalysts due to the particle size and/or poor long range order. In such a case, the (Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure) EXAFS technique can be a convenient tool for information to be obtained concerning the local structural arrangement. The present article is devoted to an EXAFS study, at the niobium K-edge, of some carbon- and alumina-supported niobium sulfide catalysts. This study was undertaken in order to establish correlations between nature of the active species and synthesis parameters, including characteristics of the support. Additionally, it provided an opportunity to check the efficacy of using an asymmetric distance distribution function for EXAFS data processing in the case of highly disordered materials. 2. Experimental 2.1. Preparation of the supported niobium sulfide catalysts Due to its remarkable mechanical characteristics, alumina is generally preferred as a catalyst support for industrial hydrotreatment processes. However, our first attempts to prepare alumina-supported niobium sulfide catalysts were unsuccessful N. Allali et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 333-354 335 because niobium-containing precursors cannot be sulfided on this support by usual methods [10]. For this reason, part of our work was carried out using the carbon support, which allows easy sulfidation of niobium. In parallel, we undertook investigations in order to sulfide niobium on the alumina support and found that sulfidation can be achieved using as the sulfiding agent carbon disulfide under pressure. The supports we used were "Norit RX3" carbon (CN), "Lonza" carbon (CL) and "GFSC" alumina. Their surface areas and pore volumes are 1200 m2/g and 1 cm3/g for CN, 225 m2/g and 1 cm3/g for CL, and 256 m2/g and 0.6 cm3/g for alumina. All the catalysts were prepared [8] by impregnation of the support with an oxalic buffer solution of niobium oxalate (about 10 g Nb/L), the niobium amount being equal to 10% of the support mass. For the alumina-supported catalysts, the niobium loading was achieved in one single impregnation. For the carbon- supported catalysts, two impregnations were used with half the required volume of solution, and with intermediate drying at room-temperature. Double impreg- nation was used for the synthesis of Nb/CN because, compared to single impreg- nation, it was found to increase the catalytic activity (thiophene HDS) threefold [8]. Nb/CL was also prepared using the double impregnation method, for the two carbon-supported samples differ only concerning the support characteristics; however, with the "Lonza" carbon support, the two methods give similar activities. Single impregnation was chosen for the three alumina-supported catalysts because double impregnation did not increase their activity. For the carbon-supported samples, sulfidation of niobium was achieved under atmospheric pressure at 400, during 4 h, using a N2/H2S (15%) flow. Unfortu- nately, this process is completely uneffective in the case of the alumina-supported samples for which more severe conditions are required: for these catalysts, sulfidation was carried out under CS2 pressure (~40 bar) at 400 for 13 h (Nbl/A1203), 400 for 100 h (Nb2/A1203) and 450~C for 4 h (Nb3/A1203). In order to be used as references, supported MoS2 samples were prepared with the same cation amount as the niobium sulfide catalysts ( 10% of the support mass). 2.2. Characterization X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on an INEL device with a curved multi- cell detector, using CuKa 1 radiation (A= 1.54059 A). EDX analysis and estimation of the active particle size were performed (when possible) using a Philips CM30 device operated at 300 kV. For EDX analysis, crystalline NbS2 was used as reference compound. 2.3. Catalytic activities Catalytic activities were measured after stabilization (16 h) in the model- reaction of thiophene hydrodesulfurization (HDS), at 350, under hydrogen flow 336 N. Allali et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 333-354 (50 cm3/mn) at atmospheric pressure, using a thiophene partial pressure of 18 Torr. The catalytic activities are expressed as the number of thiophene moles trans- formed per second and per gram of cation (Nb or Mo). 2.4. EXAFS measurements and data analysis 2.4.1. EXAFS measurements The EXAFS spectra were recorded at the Laboratoire d'Utilisation du Rayonne- ment Electromagn&ique (LURE), the French Synchrotron Laboratory, on the EXAFS I spectrometer, using a Si (3 3 1) channel cut monochromator. During the experiments, the storage ring (DCI) used 1.85 GeV positrons with an average intensity of 250 mA. Data were collected in transmission mode by measurement of the beam intensities I0 and L respectively before and after passing through the sample, using ionization chambers partially filled with argon. For preparation of samples, each material was uniformly dispersed, and sandwiched between two X- ray transparent adhesive tapes (Kapton). The measurements were performed at the Nb K-edge from 18 850 to 19 800 eV with 3 eV steps and one second accumulation time per point. The experiments were carried out at room-temperature for the alumina-supported catalysts samples and at 77 K for the carbon-supported ones. Low-temperature measurements were preferred in the second case because of the highly disordered character of this second series. 2.4.2. EXAFS data analysis The EXAFS data processing was performed following the single scattering procedure [ 11 ]. The absorption spectra to be analyzed were obtained by averaging three experimental spectra using a cumulative approach. The background absorp- tion was calculated by using a theoretical expression [12] and the single atomic absorption of the absorber was interpolated by a fifth-degree polynomial expres- sion between 19 010 and 19 800 eV. Each spectrum was carefully extracted by varying both the degree and first point of the polynomial, and the best removal of low frequency noise was checked by further Fourier transformation. The edge energy, Eo, was taken equal to 18986 eV at half height of the absorption. The pseudo radial distribution function (RDF) around the absorbing atom was then obtained by a Fourier transformation of the weighted w(k).k3.X(k) spectrum, where a;(k) is a weighting window using a Kaiser function (7-=3.5) defined between 3 and 15 ~-1. All the further back Fourier transforms included a removal of this window. EXAFS spectra were fitted by using simplex and gradient methods [13] on a single scattering spherical wave model based on tabulated amplitudes and phase shifts calculated by the FEFF 6 Code [14,15]. This procedure is known to be valid as far as multiple scattering can be neglected, as we checked through calculations including multiple scattering (FEFF 6 Code [ 15]). For all calculations, the number of refined parameters was taken lower or equal to (Nind--1), where Nind is the number of independent variables [16]. N. Results and discussion 3.1. Characterizations 3.1.1. X-ray diffraction The carbon-supported catalysts do not give any significant diffraction line. As for the alumina-supported phases, only one broad, weak line was detected in the diffractograms: at d~5.7 A for Nbl and d~5.9 ,~ for Nb2 and Nb3. These lines are consistent with the Nbl_yS 100-line [23] and NbS2 002- or 003-line of the 2H- or 3R-variety [24] respectively; however such a broad and weak unique line is not enough to allow definitive structural identification. From the line-widths, the coherence lengths can be estimated to ca. 30 ,~ along the radial direction. This value has to be considered only as a rough estimate since the Bragg peak description becomes unsuitable for so small coherence lengths. 3.1.2. Dispersion Due to very poor contrast, it was impossible to observe the carbon-supported active particles by electron microscopy. However, considering the EXAFS results (vide infra), it appears that crystalline organization is very imperfect for Nb/CN and slightly better for Nb/CL. As for the alumina-supported niobium sulfides, they show very poor dispersion [8]; all three appear rather similar, with particles of substantial length and stacking. Average length approaches 100 nm and 20-layer stackings can be found. Because of the presence of such large particles, it would be questionable to quantify the dispersion in order to compare the three catalysts in this regard. Considering the coherence length estimated hereabove, it can be deduced that the large particles are in fact aggregates constituted of small-size crystallites. 3.1.3. Chemical composition 3.1.3.1. Carbon-supported niobium sulfides. Chemical analysis (combustion) of Nb/CN gave a S/Nb ratio (3.2) greater than allowed by the chemistry of bulk niobium sulfides (maximal S/Nb ratio: 3), which is possibly related to particle size since for a given phase the overall composition depends upon the dispersion. For this reason, chemical analysis does not permit phase identification when dispersion has not been quantified: for instance smaller S/Nb ratio observed for Nb/CL (2.6) could be due to different nature of the active species and/or to larger particle size. TPR measurements were carried out on carbon-supported niobium sulfide and some of them were already reported [8]. For instance, 3.1 sulfur atoms per Nb atom were removed from Nb/CN. However, the device which was used (Tmax--1100 K) did not allow complete removal of sulfur. We note that, even if total sulfur amount N. Alumina-supported niobium sulfides. These catalysts contain significant amounts of adsorbed CS2, which distorts the results of chemical analysis and TPR measurements as well. However, for these materials, rather good contrast and large particle size allow EDX determination of the atomic S/Nb ratio in the active phase. This ratio was found smaller for Nbl/A1203 (S/Nb=I.0) than for the two other samples (S/Nb=2.1). 3.1.4. Catalytic activities Table 1 gives the catalytic activities in thiophene HDS for the five niobium sulfide supported catalysts concerned by the present study. In order to allow comparisons, activities are also given in this table, for the same reaction, for MoS2 supported on CN, CL, and A1203. Nb/CN has a higher activity than any of the tested MoS2 samples. However, its activity is much lower than that of a Co-Mo or Ni-Mo catalyst, and cobalt and nickel were not found to promote niobium sulfides [3,9]. 3.2. EXAFS study 3.2.1. The reference crystalline compounds NbS2 and NbSs Niobium disulfide (NbSz), was used as a first reference compound to determine S~ and F. For these calculations, the structural parameter N previously derived from X-ray diffraction data was introduced as a non-refinable parameter. Using these S2 and F values, the EXAFS spectrum of NbS3, the second reference, was then refined in order to check the validity of calculations (agreement between 340 N. Allali et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 333-354 EXAFS and X-ray diffraction results). Furthermore, both references were used to compare, in the case of crystalline materials, the descriptions obtained on the basis of symmetric and asymmetric distance distributions. These results will be useful as terms of comparison for the values refined for the supported catalysts. 3.2.1.1. Crystal structure. (a) NbS2 (Fig. l(a)) is a lamellar compound [24]. Its structure is built from homoatomic layers: sulfur layers and niobium layers. Three neighboring layers, a sulfur one, a niobium one, and a sulfur one ,gain, are associated by strong Nb-S bonds to form a [SNbS] slab. In such a slab, every niobium atom is prismatically surrounded by six sulfur atoms. The whole crystal arrangement results from the stacking of slabs, but inter-slab bonds are weak, which is responsible for the anisotropy of the properties of such layered compounds. (b) In NbS3 (Fig. l(b)) [7], the elementary unit is also a [NbS6] triangular prism. Every niobium has two other sulfur neighbors, so that its effective coordination number is 8 (bicapped prism). The way these prisms are associated is quite different from that of NbS2: sharing their triangular bases, they constitute infinite fibres. However, the structure of NbS3 is two-dimensional due to inter-fiber bonds involving niobium and its bicapping sulfur neighbors. In NbS3, contrary to NbS2, the triangular bases of the [NbS6] prism are not equilateral, but only roughly isosceles, with a short S-S distance which corresponds to the existence of a S-S bond. The sulfur atoms concerned form disulfide anionic pairs, S2-, whereas the third sulfur of the triangular base occurs as S2-. This means that niobium has a +IV oxidation state, with a d~ electronic configuration. For energetic reasons (better stability) niobium pairs are formed due to dl--d1 bonds, which results in an alternation of short and long Nb-Nb distances. 3.2.1.2. NbS2 and NbS3 entities can clearly be distinguished from EXAFS results due to their very different Nb-Nb contributions. Carbon-supported niobium sulfides: Two supports with different surface areas Among the carbon-supported catalysts studied, two samples, Nb/CL and Nb/CN, have been chosen to illustrate the sensitivity of niobium sulfide chemistry to support effects. In addition, the use of an asymmetric distance distribution for disordered materials will be illustrated. The two catalysts, Nb/CL and Nb/CN, contain the same amount of niobium and differ only in the characteristics of the carbon support. On the basis of these comparisons, it could be thought that NbS3 supported species are more active than NbS2 ones, in agreement with the behavior of the corresponding unsupported catalysts. Allali et aL /Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 333-354 An important result of this study is that the best activity on the alumina-support is obtained for catalysts composed of Nb~_yS-like species. This point will be discussed in Section 3.2.4. As shown by the intensities of the peaks in the RDF's and refined values of s, the crystalline organization of the active phase is rather good, at least concerning the first neighbor shell, in these alumina-supported catalysts. Moreover, the active particles are quite large if compared to those of industrial CoMo or NiMo [27,28]. Considering this very poor dispersion, the activities we reach in thiophene HDS (and in some other hydrotreatment model reactions as well) indicate that niobium sulfides are highly active. Careful optimization of the successive steps of the synthesis is currently in progress, in order to improve the dispersion, and the activity, of these catalysts. 3.2.4. Comparison of carbon- and alumina-supported niobium sulfide catalysts In this article only some of the numerous catalysts are mentioned which we prepared using alumina and carbon supports. Considering the whole set of catalysts we studied, a striking feature is that, whereas NbS2 species can be evidenced on both supports, NbS3 entities form only on carbon and Nbl_yS ones only on alumina, whatever the synthesis conditions. Concerning Nbl_yS, it has to be pointed out that attempts to synthesize bulk samples systematically resulted in polyphasic products [23]. It thus appears that Nbl_yS is stabilized by the alumina support. Besides, as already indicated, sulfidation of the niobium precursor can easily be achieved on the carbon support using a N2/H2S (15%) flow under atmospheric pressure, whereas much more severe treatment (CS2 under pressure) is required for the alumina-supported catalysts. It follows from these results that the chemistry of niobium sulfides largely depends upon the support that is used: the chemical consequences of support effects therefore appear to be more important for niobium than for molybdenum sulfides.Cation clustering, a decisive feature for high catalytic activity? At the very beginning of the study of niobium sulfide catalysts [4], the first hypothesis to explain the high activity of unsupported NbS3, compared to niobium or molybdenum disulfides, was to attribute an important catalytic role to the 2 sulfur pairs $2-. However, it appears that this anionic pairing is not sufficient for a hydrotreatment catalyst to be highly active, since titanium or zirconium trisulfides - with sulfur pairs too - are perfectly inactive [10]. It could then be thought that the high activity of NbS3 could be related to the other electronic peculiarity of this phase, i.e. cationic pairing through dl-d~ bonds (which does not exist in TiS3 and ZrS3 in which the cation external configuration is dO). For our Nb/CN catalyst, which is more active than MoS2 on the same support, it appears that part of the niobium atoms have a sulfur environment similar to that in NbS3. However, this similarity with NbS3 is not sufficient to definitively prove the importance of cation pairing since the weak Nb-Nb contribution did not allow the cationic environment of niobium to be identified. Concerning alumina-sup- ported niobium sulfides, despite its low S/Nb ratio and very poor dispersion, one of N. Allali et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 333-354 353 our catalysts matches MoS2/A1203 (Table 1). A striking feature is that the EXAFS results clearly show that this catalyst is characterized by the existence of metal- metal associations (short Nb-Nb distances typical of the Nbl_yS structural arrangement). The role of metal-metal associations has been demonstrated for hydrotreatment ruthenium sulfide catalysts, for which the best activities are reached for sulfur-deficient materials, with ruthenium clustering [29]. In Co- and Ni-promoted molybdenum sulfide catalysts, the Mo-(Ni or Co) distance is short (2.8 A [26,30]), which denotes strong metal-metal interactions. These observations do not allow us to definitively conclude that cation clustering necessarily induces high hydrotreatment catalytic activity; it is however remark- able that highly active systems contain species with cation clustering. 4. Conclusion In this work we show that, for poorly organized materials, it is of paramount importance to use a suitable model for description of the distance distribution. For the crystalline references, and for our alumina-supported catalysts in which the Nb-S species exhibit a rather good crystalline organization, correct results are obtained using either gaussian or asymmetric distance distributions. In contrast, for our poorly crystallized carbon-supported catalysts, the gaussian description leads to structural parameters devoid of chemical meaning, and precludes precise identification of the niobium sulfide entities. In such a case, an asymmetric distance distribution model has to be used, since it is the only way for significant parameters to be refined and the nature of the active species established. This study shows that various niobium sulfide species can be synthesized by varying the nature of the support and synthesis conditions. The highest activity was obtained with the "Norit RX3" carbon support. However, because alumina is preferred for industrial use, it is on alumina-supported niobium sulfides that we will focus future efforts. Effectively, considering the poor morphologic character- istics of the present alumina-supported samples, the catalytic activities we measured show that niobium sulfides are intrinsically highly active. Moreover, as we have previously shown, if compared to molybdenum-based formulations, they have interesting specific properties. Future work will be devoted to a systematic optimization of the different steps of the synthesis of alumina-supported niobium sulfides, in order to improve the dispersion and activity of these promising catalysts.
